translated: Sutra of the Wise and the Foolish, Scroll 24
Translated by the Yao Qin Dynasty monk Zhu Fonian from Liangzhou
Chapter 28: Contemplation, Contemplation
Contemplate one's own faults well, so that they are not exposed externally.
Each has their own faults, like those light dust particles flying about.

Contemplate one's own faults well means that people only see the faults of others and not their own shortcomings. They argue with each other, mutually slandering, just like the person in charge of the threshing floor who scoops up the grain, blows it high, and the light ones go far away while the heavy ones stay close. Therefore it is said, Contemplate one's own faults well, so that they are not exposed externally. Each has their own faults, like those light dust particles flying about.
If one claims to be flawless, both matters will arrive together.
Only seeing the faults of outsiders, always harboring thoughts of harm,
Far away, one does not see what is near.

In the world, people often deceive themselves with praise, claiming their own merits to be unparalleled in the world, saying, My practice of precepts, listening to the Dharma, giving, and wisdom are supreme, unique, and unmatched. Therefore, it is said, If one claims to be flawless.

Both matters arrive together refers to those who cover up their own faults. Those who go against it gain victory, while those who follow it are always defeated. The practice of cultivating virtue is also like this. Knowing one's own faults but not revealing them, seeing others' faults, therefore it is said, Both matters arrive together.

Only seeing others' faults, always harboring thoughts of harm means that people do not examine themselves but only see the various unwholesome dharmas and the calamities of evil outside. Falling into evil destinies, not reaching good places, experiencing the sufferings of hell, animals, and hungry ghosts, therefore it is said, Only seeing others' faults, always harboring thoughts of harm.

Space and earth are each separate, not seeing the true Dharma and not seeing the non-true Dharma. Therefore it is said, Far away, one does not see the near.ğŸ”½Knowing shame is the best among long lives,
Hawks greedily snatch and pounce,
Strong men have no fear or avoidance, their lives are short.

As for knowing shame is the best among long lives, when people live in the world, not knowing shame and having nothing to fear or avoid, they are like a violent bull that has nothing to fear or avoid. That foolish person is also like this, giving rise to actions without fear or avoidance. Therefore it is said, knowing shame is the best among long lives.

As for hawks greedily snatch and pounce, it is like how flying hawks greedily eat without satiation, snatching and pouncing on people and things without any sense of moderation. Sentient beings are also like this, greedily attached to wealth and desires without ever being content. Therefore it is said, hawks greedily snatch and pounce.

As for the fearless and reckless one like a strong man, it is like that powerful person who has nothing to fear or difficulty, in the great assembly he does as he pleases without anyone being able to match him, if there are those who come to admonish and persuade him, he immediately becomes angry and cuts off their life-force. Therefore it is said, fearless and reckless like a strong man.

As for those whose lives are short, in this world people look down on others and value themselves, they only hold onto delusion and are confused and do not awaken, they encroach on the property of the Three Jewels and rely on their own strength, for such people their lives do not last long. Therefore it is said, those whose lives are short.
Those who know shame do not exhaust their lives, always seeking pure conduct,
With unimpaired deportment, one should contemplate true pure life.

Knowing shame does not exhaust one's life means that a person who is ashamed and has a sense of shame is not very diligent in seeking clothing and food. The wealth and goods they obtain are distributed to others. They wear coarse clothes and eat poor food, without adornments. They only maintain their lives in the world without any glory or hope. Therefore, it is said, Knowing shame does not exhaust one's life.

Always seeking pure conduct means that one's conduct is pure and does not create wrong paths. One's body, speech, and mind are pure and should accord with the unsurpassed conduct. One also knows external purity and speaks appropriately without harming others. Therefore, it is said, Always seeking pure conduct.
Deportment without leakage means restraining the senses and not letting them run wild. Therefore, it is said, Deportment without leakage.

One should contemplate true purity and longevity means that one's advance and retreat, coming and going, speech, food and drink, and seeking to sustain one's life are all in accordance with the truth. Therefore, it is said, One should contemplate true purity and longevity.
The world is universally blind and dark, with few having eyes to see,
Many birds fall into the net, but it is not enough to say they are reborn in the heavens.

Those who are completely blind in the world are like the blind who do not see good colors, bad colors, flat ground, or high cliffs. This kind of sentient being is also like this, covered by lust, anger, and delusion, not seeing the practices of good and evil, not knowing what is beautiful or ugly, and also not knowing the laws of white and black. The mind is confused and does not seek good places. Therefore, it is said that the world is completely blind.
Those who have eyes are few and far between. It is as explained in the Long Ä€gama Sutra. The Buddha told the long-nailed brahman:
In the world, those who cultivate goodness are very few.

To put it simply, sentient beings with inverted views are more numerous than the earth's soil. They do not recognize the Buddha, the Dharma, the bhiká¹£u saá¹…gha, or their parents, and they also do not distinguish between superiors and inferiors, or high and low.
Sentient beings with right views are like the soil on a fingernail. Although their views are not mistaken, their aspirations and pursuits are not the same;

It is like the non-Buddhist brÄhmaá¹‡as and Nirgranthas who have left home to study the path, each considering themselves superior. Their scriptures are different, seeking liberation, grasping foolish thoughts and confused intentions, not reaching the great path, those with right views are mostly not enough to speak of.
Therefore, it is said, Those with eyes are few.
As for birds falling into a net, it is like a hunter setting up a net and a snare to catch countless birds and animals, and only one or two of them escape;
The multitude of beings reborn in the heavens is also like this, only one or two of them attain the blessings of the heavens.
As it is said in the Saá¹ƒyuktÃ¢gama SÅ«tra, the Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
The number of beings entering hell is greater than the amount of earth, from hell they end up returning to hell, the same is true for hungry ghosts and animals;
Beings reborn in the heavens are like the amount of soil on a fingernail.
Therefore, it is said, Birds in a net, rebirth in the heavens is also like this.
Observing the world's decaying phenomena, one only sees the transformation of various forms.
The foolish bind themselves, wrapped in darkness.

Observing the world's decaying phenomena, one only sees the transformation of various forms means that when people are in the world, they go through a thousand twists and turns, and their conduct is not the same.
There are three things in the world:
First, the world of vessels; second, the world of aggregates; third, the world of sentient beings.
The so-called world of vessels refers to the trichiliocosm.
The world of sentient beings refers to the sentient beings of the three realms and the four modes of birth and five destinies.
The world of aggregates refers to the form aggregate and the formless aggregate.
Within the three worlds, the realm of sentient beings is taken.
Why is it said to be the Dharma of decay?

The so-called Dharma of decay is decayed by desire, anger, and delusion, just as a merchant traveling far on the road encounters a thief and loses the wealth and treasures he has obtained, being robbed by the thief;

This kind of sentient being is also like this. They are robbed by lust, anger, and delusion, and their wholesome roots and wealth are cut off. Many people see and know their decline. Among the billions and millions, there are occasionally those who escape. Therefore, it is said, Observing the law of worldly decline, one only sees the change of various forms.

The foolish bind themselves and are wrapped in darkness. In the world, there are many people with different practices. They are always bound by two fetters: first, afflictions; second, the fetters of the aggregates.
Bound by these two things, covered by ignorance, they are also unable to attain realization by skipping stages, to exhaust defilements and attain purity.

It is like a criminal who is imprisoned and does not see the light of the sun and moon. This kind of sentient being is also like this. Covered by the dark room of ignorance, bound by desire, anger, and delusion, it is difficult for them to seek liberation.
Therefore it is said, The foolish bind themselves, wrapped in darkness.

Also, not seeing any practice, observing that there is nothing, using nature to contemplate, not seeing the basis of merit at all, and again using the knowledge of others' minds, for those who wish to escape this difficulty, there is not a single wholesome root that can save them;

Just as if a person were drowning in a deep cesspool, and there were a compassionate person who wished to save them from that difficulty, seeking a clean place to go and grab them, looking everywhere without finding a single clean place, then giving up and leaving.
A person without outflows observes sentient beings, is there even a trace of wholesome roots that can be treated?
Thoroughly observing them, there are no wholesome roots that can be treated, and the sage thinks to themselves:
Alas, the decline of the multitude, their offenses are heavy, reaching this point.
Therefore it is said, Also, not seeing any practice, observing that there is nothing.
Sentient beings all have a self, and for them, suffering arises.
Each one does not see the other, and does not see the thorn of wrong views.

Sentient beings all have a self, and for them, suffering arises: In the world, there are many people whose nature harbors perversions. Sentient beings think that they are created by themselves, or that they are born from themselves.
There are also those who say that they are born from others, or that they exist because of others.
Therefore, it is said that sentient beings all have a self, and for them, suffering arises.

Each one does not see the other, and does not see the thorn of wrong views: Each one refers to the non-Buddhist Brahmins. They do not contemplate right views but believe in wrong perversions. Therefore, it is said that each one does not see the other, and does not see the thorn of wrong views.
Observing this thorn, sentient beings are attached to it.
What I create does not exist for them, what they create does not exist for me.

As for contemplating the causes and conditions of this thorn, what is called a thorn is the thorn of wrong views. As for causes and conditions, they are the hells, hungry ghosts, animals, humans, and gods, each with different and dissimilar seeds. Therefore, it is said to contemplate the causes and conditions of this thorn.

Beings are attached to it. Non-Buddhist practitioners and students of other paths, day and night, diligently and busily, each consider themselves to be truly believing in wrong and inverted views, unable to let go and follow the right path. Therefore, it is said that beings are attached to it.

I create it, but it does not exist. They create it, but it does not exist. Each considers themselves to be correct, but they mutually interfere with each other. The various types of beings think, I create it and I make it, it does not belong to them. They also think to themselves,
They create it and they make it, it does not belong to me.
Therefore, it is said, I create it, but it does not exist. They create it, but it does not exist.
Beings are entangled by arrogance and attachment to arrogance,
Being deluded by views, one cannot escape the bounds of birth and death.
Sentient beings are entangled by arrogance, attached to arrogance. That person thinks to himself, My mind and nature are arrogant:
I am now the most honored and supreme in the assembly. My clan, family background, house, land, fields, servants, and family lineage are unmatched by anyone else.
The mind is firm and cannot let go. Therefore it is said, Sentient beings are entangled by arrogance, attached to arrogance.

Being deluded by views, one cannot escape the bounds of birth and death. The view of permanence is not in accord with the view of annihilation, and the view of annihilation is not in accord with the view of permanence. One cannot escape this birth and death to reach the shore of the unconditioned. Therefore it is said, Being deluded by views, one cannot escape the bounds of birth and death.
Having attained and about to attain, both receive defilements,
Cultivating the root of illness, and studying all that is to be studied,
Observing those who uphold the precepts, people of pure spiritual practice,
And those who care for the sick and weak, this is called reaching the ultimate.

There are sentient beings in the world whose wrong views are intense, who are attached to desires and cannot let go, who take pure desires and indulge in them, and who give rise to arrogance and do not change themselves. This is called the second extreme. This is called the wise ones increasing attachments.

Those who have attained and will attain, who have obtained the aggregates and sense bases, and those who have not obtained the aggregates and sense bases, both of these receive defilements: one is the defilement of wrong views, the other is the defilement of desire, they are bound by afflictions and cannot let go. Therefore it is said, both receive the defilements of dust.

As for practicing at the root of illness, non-Buddhist practitioners are like this. They practice their skills and take pride in themselves, and study all that is to be studied. All sentient beings who study their skills, such as riding horses, driving chariots, and creating all kinds of things, are able to master them all. Those who possess this practice attain liberation. Therefore it is said, And study all that is to be studied.

As for observing those who uphold precepts, there are Brahmins who uphold precepts. Some uphold the crow precept, making sounds like a crow. Some uphold the bald owl precept, kneeling and bowing at the right time, imitating the cry of a bald owl. Some uphold the deer precept, making sounds like a deer. Therefore it is said, Observing those who uphold precepts.
As for Brahmins who are pure people, those non-Buddhist practitioners say to each other:

Those who practice purity in pairs attain liberation and reach a pure place. If one serves fire, the sun, the moon, the divine pearl, medicinal herbs, clothing, palaces, and houses, one will then reach the state of no-action.
This is called the extreme of one side.

In the world, there are sentient beings with strong wrong views, who are attached to desires and cannot let go of them, considering desires to be pure. Outsiders practice them, committing desires without restraint. This is called the wise ones increasing attachments. Those who can understand this are also not subject to the cycle of birth and death.
Those with eyes observe. Those with eyes are the Buddhas, the World-Honored Ones. Faith can observe the cessation of the cycle of birth and death. Therefore, it is said, What those with eyes see.
Those who understand these two extremes are unstained and unattached, and do not give rise to afflictions. This is called the extreme.
Contemplate the bubbles on water, and also contemplate the mirage,
If one does not contemplate the body in this way, one will not see the king of death.
Contemplate the bubbles on water, and also contemplate the mirage. Like those bubbles on water, they cannot last long.

In the past, there was a king's daughter who was loved by the king and had never been away from his eyes. At that time, it rained and there were bubbles on the water. The daughter saw the bubbles in the water and thought of them with great love and respect. The daughter said to the king:
I want to get the bubbles on the water to make a flower garland for my head.
The king said to the daughter:
Now the bubbles on the water cannot be obtained, how can I get them to make a flower garland?
The daughter said to the king:
If I cannot get them, I will kill myself.
When the king heard the daughter's words, he summoned the skilled craftsmen and said to them:
You are all skilled and understand everything. Quickly get the water bubbles and make a garland for my daughter. If you do not, I will have you executed!
The skilled craftsmen said to the king:
We are not able to get the bubbles to make a garland.
Among them, there was an old craftsman who volunteered to be able to get the bubbles. He then came forward and said to the king:
I am able to get the bubbles and make a garland for the king.
The king was very happy and told his daughter:
Now there is a person who is suitable to make the garland. You can go yourself and personally inspect.
The daughter followed the king's words and looked outside. The old craftsman said to the king's daughter:
I have never distinguished the good and bad of water bubbles. I only pray that the king's daughter will personally pick the bubbles and I will make the garland.

The daughter then picked the bubbles, but they broke as soon as she touched them and she could not get them. In this way, she searched all day but could not find any bubbles. The daughter became tired and gave up.
The daughter said to the king:
Water bubbles are illusory and cannot last long. I only pray that the king will make a purple gold garland for me. It will not wither all day and night.
Water bubbles deceive people's eyes. Although they have form and substance, they are born and die as soon as they are born.

The mirage is also like this. Thirst, fatigue, and toil lead to the loss of one's life. The human body is false and deceptive, with little pleasure and much suffering. It is subject to destruction and cannot last long. It changes and transforms, and there is little of it in the world. If one is not seen by the king of death, then it is said, Contemplate the bubbles on water, and also contemplate the mirage. If one does not contemplate the body in this way, one will not see the king of death.
Contemplate the bubbles on water, and also contemplate the mirage.
If one does not contemplate the world in this way, one will not see the king of death.
Not contemplating the world means that the five aggregates of the body will soon be extinguished. If one can extinguish this body of five aggregates, then one will not meet the king of death.
Thus one should contemplate the body, like a chariot of various colors belonging to a king.
The foolish are attached to it, but the wise seek to be far away from it.

One should contemplate the body like a king's multicolored chariot means that just as a king's chariot is adorned with various colors, although it has form and color, it is not solid and cannot bear heavy loads. Therefore it is said, One should contemplate the body like a king's multicolored chariot.

The foolish are attached to it, but the wise seek to be far away from it means that what fools crave and practice, the wise discard like throwing away filth. Therefore it is said, The foolish are attached to it, but the wise seek to be far away from it.
One should contemplate the body like a king's multicolored chariot,
The foolish are attached to it, but the wise are far away from it.

The wise know that it is impermanent and unstable, and their minds do not delight in it. They always wish to be far away from it, avoiding it like a disaster. Therefore it is said, The wise are far away from it.
One should contemplate the body as the cause of various illnesses,
Illness combines with foolishness, how can one rely on it?ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

People emerge from the womb due to causes and conditions from past lives. Many illnesses, few illnesses, good and ugly appearances, therefore it is said, Thus should one contemplate the body, the cause of various illnesses. Illness and foolishness combine, how can one rely on it?
One should contemplate the painted image, with hair dark blue like a maá¹‡i jewel.
Foolish ones take it as a condition, not seeking to cross to the other shore.

One should contemplate the painted image, with hair dark blue like a maá¹‡i jewel means to perfume the hair with various fragrances and bathe it with fragrant water, the fragrant scent spreads far, therefore it is said, One should contemplate the painted image, with hair dark blue like a maá¹‡i jewel.

Foolish ones take it as a condition, not seeking to cross to the other shore means that foolish ones are entangled and unable to be far removed, without skillful means to reach the other shore. The so-called other shore is the extinction of nirvana, therefore it is said, Foolish ones take it as a condition, not seeking to cross to the other shore.
One should contemplate the painted image, with hair the color of a sapphire gem,
The foolish take it as a condition, while the wise are disgusted with it.
A wise person distinguishes and contemplates subtle observations, and does not give rise to attachment. Therefore it is said, The wise are disgusted with it.
Strongly using colorful paintings to adorn an ugly and filthy body,
The foolish take it as a condition, and do not seek liberation for themselves.
In the past, there was a wealthy family with abundant wealth and the seven treasures complete. The elder thought to himself:
Now young monks have not yet severed their desires. I should invite them to come to my home and have the women serve them food and make offerings. If there are any with lustful desires, I will know.
He then went to the temple to invite the young monks to the elder's home. The women adorned themselves in new clothes and all came out to pay respects, giving rise to an attitude of reverence.

At that time, there was an arhat with the six spiritual powers who immediately became aware of it. He transformed the dead person's bones and flesh into a skull and bones scattered in different places.
Then the arhat told the monks:
You should concentrate your minds on seeking liberation, do not look at women's forms and give rise to defiled thoughts.
At that time, the elder saw that auspicious sign and marveled at it. He reproached himself and knew it was not right. He threw himself to the ground and repented:
I now know the subtlety of the Dharma.
The women were each ashamed and returned to their homes.
At that time, the arhat told the elder:

The Buddha's teachings are vast and boundless. You now use the wisdom of an ordinary person to measure the sages. This is not the right principle. It is like comparing a handful of dirt to Mount Sumeru, or using a small container to measure the ocean.
At that time, the monk spoke this verse:
Though forcefully painted with colorful patterns, adorning an ugly and filthy body,
The foolish take it as a condition, and do not seek liberation for themselves.
Dividing the hair into eight sections, with earrings for the two parts of the eyes and ears,
The foolish are attached to it, and do not seek liberation for themselves.
At that time, after the bhiká¹£us had spoken these two verses, they immediately rose from their seats and left.
At that time, the elder and the women gave rise to a good mind on their own, respectfully venerating the Three Jewels, and each of them later attained the path of the stream-enterer.
Attached to desires and defiled by desires, not thoroughly investigating the conditions of afflictions,
Not giving rise to afflictions, one should cross over the flowing waters of desire and existence.

As for attached to desires and defiled by desires, the groups of people in the world have different aspirations, some with few desires and some with biased and excessive desires. Those with biased and excessive desires do not understand the way of the wise. Therefore, it is said: Attached to desires and defiled by desires.

As for not investigating the causes of afflictions, greed, jealousy, and stinginess are the most serious illnesses among the sicknesses. They penetrate to the bone marrow and cannot be cured by doctors. Even if one accumulates wealth worth millions, one is unwilling to give in charity. When one's life ends, one cannot take even a single coin with oneself.

If sentient beings practice greed and jealousy, their bodies will lack majestic spiritual power and they will end up poor. Their relatives will not be harmonious and they will be looked down upon by others. Therefore, it is said, Do not investigate the causes of afflictions.
As for not giving rise to afflictions and crossing the flow of desire and existence, the flow has four categories with different matters.
What are the four?
First, the flow of desire; second, the flow of existence; third, the flow of ignorance; fourth, the flow of views.

Sentient beings sink and drown in birth and death all because of these four. They flow and wander in the four afflictions and cannot save themselves. They will continue to go through the five realms of rebirth. Therefore, it is said, Do not give rise to afflictions and cross the flow of desire and existence.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Above all, being free from desires, one should contemplate this great view,
Thus there is liberation, which was not attained before.

Above all, being free from desires means the desireless state in the form and formless realms. Desires refer to the desire realm. In these three realms, one is no longer subject to the three poisons and attains permanent liberation from them. Therefore, it is said, above all, being free from desires.

One should contemplate this great view means that a desireless person is the Buddha's foremost disciple. The Buddha has four disciples, and the arhats are the most excellent, venerable, noble, and unsurpassed. Therefore, it is said, one should contemplate this great view.

Thus there is liberation means that the sages practice for the sake of others, attain permanent mastery over the four currents, and are no longer attached to existence in their bodily and verbal actions. Therefore, it is said, thus there is liberation.

As for those who have not yet been liberated, in the past they have gone through the difficulties of birth and death, and have never been liberated. They should seek skillful means to liberate from these three realms of existence, and will no longer accept existence and create a body of the four elements. Therefore it is said, As for those who have not yet been liberated.
Not escaping from the garden, escaping from the garden and returning to the garden,
One should observe this person again, escaping from bondage and returning to bondage.
In the past, the Buddha was in the Nyagrodha Park of Kapilavastu in the country of Shakya.
At that time, the World-Honored One, at the proper time, put on his robe and took his alms bowl, and with his attendant Ananda entered the city of Kapilavastu to beg for food.

At that time, the young Nanda, on a high building, saw from afar the World-Honored One entering the city to beg for food. He quickly descended from the high building to where the World-Honored One was, bowed his head at the Buddha's feet and said to the World-Honored One:
The Tathagata's clan is a noble lineage in the country, a place where the wheel-turning sage king goes. Why do you debase yourself by holding an alms bowl to beg for food?
At that time, Nanda took the TathÄgata's bowl and went inside to fill it with delicious food and drink.
After seeing Nanda enter the house, the Buddha told Ä€nanda:
I will now go to the Nyagrodha Park. If Nanda comes out, do not take the bowl again.
Tell Nanda:
'Personally deliver the bowl back to the TathÄgata.'
Nanda accepted the instruction and followed behind to deliver the bowl. His wife followed behind and said to Nanda:
Return quickly, do not stay long. Come back to eat.
Before long, the wife sent a message again:
Return in time, do not linger.
The reason for the repeated emphasis was fear that he would abandon the household life to study the path.
Nanda brought it to where the World-Honored One was, personally held up the bowl, and offered it to the TathÄgata, saying:
Please accept it in time, I now wish to return home.
The Buddha told Nanda:
You have come to this point, now you should leave home, shave your beard and hair, and wear the three Dharma robes. Why do you hesitate and want to return home?
At that time, the TathÄgata used his majestic spiritual power to force Nanda to leave home and become a monk, locking him in a quiet room and not allowing him to return home.
In this way, as the days and months passed, the turn eventually came to Nanda.
When Nanda heard this, he was delighted inside, thinking:
I will now have a chance to relax. I will take this opportunity to escape and return home.
At that time, Nanda accepted the turn and prepared water and swept the ground, not lacking in anything.

At that time, the heavenly beings guarded Nanda, drawing water until it naturally overflowed and was discarded in the clean ground. The grass and soil became more luxuriant, and the door that was closed naturally opened.
Nanda thought:
My home is of royal lineage, with abundant wealth and treasures, lacking nothing. I will now escape and return home.
If there is any loss, I will make it up with my own possessions. Now I will sneak along a small path, and those who follow the main road will all meet the Tathagata.
At that time Nanda took off his three Dharma robes, put on white clothes, and left.

Before he had gone far, he happened to meet the Tathagata coming from the opposite direction. When Nanda saw this, he ran to a large tree, wanting to hide his form, but by the Tathagata's spiritual power the large tree was made to stand behind Nanda. Nanda was flustered, not knowing where to go.
At that time the World-Honored One again used his spiritual power to pull up the large tree and suspend it in the air.
At that time Nanda entered the root of the tree, hiding his form to conceal himself, but the Tathagata went there and met him.
Nanda!
Why have you come here?
Nanda remained silent, ashamed and not responding.
The Tathagata spoke to Nanda a second and third time, saying:
Where do you want to go? Why do you remain silent and not respond?
Nanda said:
I want to return home to see my wife.
The Buddha told Nanda:
When people study the Way, their minds are not focused, greedy for desires, not caring about the calamity of burning the body in the next world.
At that time, the World-Honored One then spoke a verse, saying:
Not escaping from the garden, escaping from the garden and returning to the garden,
One should observe this person, escaping from bondage and returning to bondage.
I will now take you to the heavens to observe. You should be focused and not be afraid.
At that time, the World-Honored One used his supernormal powers to take Nanda by the hand and bring him to the heavens.
He saw a palace made of the seven treasures, with jade maidens and attendants beyond measure, all women with no men and no husbands.
At that time, Nanda came forward and said to the Buddha:
What is this heavenly palace, with incomparable bliss?
The seven-treasure halls play the zither and drums, with singing and dancing entertainment, unlike anything heard before.
However, these heavenly maidens have no husbands. I only wish that the World-Honored One would resolve my doubts.
At that time, the World-Honored One told Nanda:
You go there yourself and ask about the truth.
The heavenly maiden will herself tell you.
Nanda, following the instruction, went to the heavenly palace and asked the heavenly maiden about the truth:
You heavenly maidens naturally enjoy blessings. You have palaces made of the seven treasures and the five kinds of music for your own entertainment. Where are your husbands?
The heavenly maiden replied:
Don't you know?

In the country of Kapilavastu in JambudvÄ«pa, there is a Buddha named ÅšÄkyamuni. His younger brother is named Nanda. After his life ends, he will be reborn in this heavenly palace. That person will be our husband.
When Nanda heard this, he secretly rejoiced:
The one being discussed is none other than myself!
He then returned to the Buddha and fully told the World-Honored One about this matter:
All these palaces, jade maidens, and attendants are all mine.
The Buddha told Nanda:
Quickly practice the pure life, and before long you will come here to enjoy the blessings naturally.
At that time, the World-Honored One used his supernormal powers to take Nanda by the hand and bring him to hell. On the way through the Iron Ring Mountain, he saw a blind monkey with only one eye.
The Buddha said to Nanda:
How is your wife Sundari compared to this blind monkey?
Nanda said to the Buddha:
Stop, stop, World-Honored One, do not speak of this again!
How can you compare this to that person?
Sundari is the most outstanding woman, skilled in sixty-four arts.
At that time, the World-Honored One told Nanda:
